qas.question: From which Arabic verb might "Quran" be derived?
What Syriac word might be related to "Quran"?
The words from which the name "Quran" might be described are related to which act?
Which word do most Muslim scholars point to as the origin of the Quran's name?
From which Arabic noun might "Quran" be derived?
From which Arabic verb might not "Quran" be derived?
What Syriac word might be unrelated to "Quran"?
The words from which the name "Quran" might be described are unrelated to which act?
Which word don't any Muslim scholars point to as the origin of the Quran's name?

context: The word qurʼān appears about 70 times in the Quran itself, assuming various meanings. It is a verbal noun (maṣdar) of the Arabic verb <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>qaraʼa<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> (قرأ), meaning "he read" or "he recited". The Syriac equivalent is (ܩܪܝܢܐ) <a1_0><b6_0>qeryānā<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which refers to "scripture reading" or "lesson". While some Western scholars consider the word to be derived from the Syriac, the majority of Muslim authorities hold the origin of the word is <a3_0><b8_0>qaraʼa<b8_0/><a3_0/> itself. Regardless, it had become an Arabic term by Muhammad's lifetime. An important meaning of the word is the "act of <a2_0><b7_0>reciting<b7_0/><a2_0/>", as reflected in an early Quranic passage: "It is for Us to collect it and to recite it (qurʼānahu)."
